snippet: A judge allowed a lawsuit from people who say they were wrongfully arrested for trespassing in public housing, saying New York City’s rules against loitering are too vague.
abstract: Judge Shira A Scheindlin of Federal District Court in Manhattan allows a lawsuit challenging police arrests for trespassing in housing projects to move closer to trial; says New York City's laws against loitering in public housing projects are too vague and give the police too much discretion about whom to arrest.
lead_paragraph: A judge allowed a lawsuit from people who say they were wrongfully arrested for trespassing in public housing, saying New York City’s rules against loitering are too vague.

headline.seo: Federal Judge Says Obscure Loitering Rules Are Unconstitutional
headline.main: Loitering Rules in Projects Are Too Vague, Judge Says
headline.print_headline: Loitering Rules in Projects Are Too Vague, Judge Says
